title: LING200 0101 SPRING 2025
text:
Preface
This online resource complements the in-class discussions and activities we have in our Linguistics 200 0101 section. Think of it as a dynamic guide (not a study guide!), a record of our collaborative explorations into the fascinating world of language.
Here, youâ€™ll find handouts that recap key concepts, exercises that challenge your assumptions, and prompts that encourage you to think critically about how language works. Itâ€™s not a summary of what weâ€™ve done; it is also not a sufficient set of materials for getting ready for an exam.
The materials here are designed to be interactive. Donâ€™t just read passivelyâ€”engage with the questions, discuss with your classmates, and even challenge the ideas presented. The more you interact with these materials, the more youâ€™ll get out of them.
This website is also a space for ongoing discussion and collaboration. If you have questions, insights, or even disagreements, share them! Use the Piazza forum to engage with your classmates and me. We can continue our linguistic explorations beyond the classroom walls.
Important Links:

ELMS
Piazza Forum

I hope this online resource proves to be a valuable tool in your linguistic journey. Letâ€™s keep exploring the fascinating world of language together!






Disclaimer



The information provided in this online resource is intended for educational purposes only and should not be considered a substitute for attending the in-class discussion or engaging with the course material in its entirety. Please refer to the official course materials and consult with us for any clarification or concerns. If anything here does not agree with the official course materials, assume that course materials are true.

title: 1Â  Introduction
text:
Signs are arbitrary: Thereâ€™s no inherent connection between the form of a word and its meaning.
Our job as linguists is to find patterns: We look beyond the surface of arbitrariness to discover the underlying rules of language.
Grammaticality and acceptability are not the same: What is considered â€œgrammaticalâ€ can vary depending on context, dialect, idiolect, and individual preferences.
Languages can have unexpected features: Even seemingly simple grammatical phenomena like the past tense can have hidden complexities.
â€œKnowingâ€ a language is complex: It involves more than just following prescriptive rules.

title: 1Â  Introduction
text:
1.2 Arbitrariness

1.2.1 â€œateÅŸâ€ (fire) in Different Scripts
Turkic people were nomad for almost their entire history of existence. For this reason, they ended up using many different scripts throughout their history and lived with many different cultures.



Script
Representation




Latin
ateÅŸ


Arabic
Ø¢ØªØ´


Cyrillic
Ğ°Ñ‚ĞµÑˆ


Runic
ğ°ğ°ªğ°¡ğ±


Mongolian
á ¢á ¨á ª


Judeo-Espanol
××˜×™×©


Greek
Î±Ï„Î­Ï‚


Armenian
Õ¡Õ©Õ¥Õ·



This diversity of scripts illustrates a key principle in linguistics: the arbitrariness of the sign. The connection between a wordâ€™s form (how itâ€™s written or sounds) and its meaning is, for the most part, arbitrary. Thereâ€™s no inherent reason why the sounds /ateÊƒ/ should mean â€œfireâ€ or map to any of to writings above. This is because language is a system of conventions, not a reflection of some inherent connection between sound and meaning.



1.2.2 ghoti = fish
Think about the word ghoti in English from George Bernard Shaw. Itâ€™s a classic example demonstrating the irregularities of English spelling and pronunciation, and how seemingly unrelated and arbitrary letter combinations can produce unexpected sounds. Letâ€™s break it down:

gh: This combination, as in the word enough, can be pronounced like the â€œfâ€ in fish.
o: This vowel, as in the word women, can be pronounced like the â€œiâ€ in fish.
ti: This combination, as in the word nation, can be pronounced like the â€œshâ€ in fish.

Putting it all together, ghoti could theoretically be pronounced â€œfish.â€ This isnâ€™t a real word, of course, but it perfectly illustrates the arbitrariness of the sign. Thereâ€™s no logical reason why those specific letters should combine to produce those sounds. Itâ€™s simply a quirk of English spelling conventions.


1.2.3 Name Pronunciation Challenge
Now that weâ€™ve seen how tricky spelling and pronunciation can be, letâ€™s put it into practice with a fun icebreaker! Weâ€™ll work in pairs of 2. Introduce yourself to your partner. Then, each partner will explain the otherâ€™s name to me, including pronunciation, meaning (if known), and any interesting facts about it. Just like ghoti, try to find some words that you can explain to me how I can learn to produce your names.

title: 1Â  Introduction
section: 1.3 From Arbitrariness to Patterns: The Past Tense
text:
1.3 From Arbitrariness to Patterns: The Past Tense
Our job as linguists is to look beyond the surface of this arbitrariness and find the underlying patterns and rules that govern language. Just like you did with your names, we look past the different spellings and pronunciations to find the common threads that connect them. Letâ€™s explore this with something we all use (and I sometimes mess up!) every day: the past tense in English.
How is the past tense pronounced in each of the following words? Try to ignore the spelling and really think about how you pronounce it in each case.

walked ______
crashed ______
itched ______
allowed ______
mugged ______
owned ______
needed ______
waited ______
added ______

What would be the past tense of the following verbs?

smick
frimm
spling
pling
thrim

Now, consider the past of these verbs that change in more unpredictable ways:

sing ______
swim ______
sleep ______
keep ______

How come do you know how to pronounce these words that donâ€™t exist and thus that you have not heard the past tense forms of before? Give me hypotheses!

title: 1Â  Introduction
section: 1.4 Grammaticality vs.Â Acceptability: What Does it Mean to â€œKnowâ€ a Language?
text:
1.4 Grammaticality vs.Â Acceptability: What Does it Mean to â€œKnowâ€ a Language?
Now that weâ€™ve explored the patterns of past tense formation, letâ€™s delve into some deeper questions about language itself. We often talk about sentences being â€œgrammaticalâ€ or â€œungrammatical,â€ but what does that actually mean? And how does it relate to what we consider â€œacceptableâ€ or â€œnormalâ€ language use?
Letâ€™s consider these examples and discuss their grammaticality and acceptability:



Sentence
Grammatical?
Does everyone agree?




I went to the store yesterday.




Yesterday I to the store went.




Me and my friend went to the mall.




The nanny slept the baby.




Colorless green ideas sleep furiously.




I ainâ€™t going there.




After lunch John was tired and so he laid down for a while.




Speaker A: Is Sue there? Speaker B: This is she.




Speaker A: Whereâ€™s Sue? Speaker B: Thatâ€™s she over there.




Iâ€™m pretty sure that Mary voted for myself.





Discuss your answers with a neighbor or in your small group. Does everyone in your group agree? Pay close attention to where there are disagreements. Why do you think people have different intuitions about these sentences?
Exercise Give me a sentence you or someone else in your life used that might create some disagreements in the group.
How about following sentences? Does grammaticality mean it is acceptable? Does acceptability mean it is grammatical?

The gang by the bikes were huddled.
John and Mary met in the backyard, Mike did too.
Who did Mary sing and dance with?
More people have been to China than I have.
The cheese the rat the cat chased ate perished.

text:
1.5 Finding patterns in Karodza (Hard Puzzle)







Karodza
English Translation




r bixir tusa bankaki.
The boy kissed the puppy.


r meku r timi bixi r kona pe mestatu.
The girl sees the young boy in the house.


r tusa r kona pe olkaka.
The puppy was in the house.


r timu meku r kona pe oltatu.
The young girl is in the house.


te r tusa r kona pe meskakte.
You saw the puppy in the house.


ma r meku mestatma.
I see the girl.


r timi bixi r kona pe olkaki.
The young boy was in the house.

title: 2Â  Phonetics I
text:
Existential Dog











What differentiates between human language and other communication systems?
What are the design features of languages?
Get in groups of 2-3 and (i) briefly discuss a design feature and (ii) discuss whether other communication systems has that feature.

title: 2Â  Phonetics I
text:
2.2 Sounds






Phonetics




Physiological, aerodynamic and acoustic characteristics of speech sounds.
As such really a branch of physics/biology.
Typical questions:

What does our mouth do when we say Ian as opposed to Canada?
What does the sound wave look like that is produced when we say Ian?
Do the individual sounds of a word become shorter if the word as a whole becomes longer?
What happens in our ears when we hear i as opposed to a?
Why do we sound nasal when we have a cold?










Spelling (orthography) is not phonetics.




Spelling tries to give an accurate representation of sound impressions.
English (and other languages) often fails quite miserably at that.
Spelling is about letters, phonetics is about sound.
Phonology is about the system that actually underlies all pronunciation, i.e.Â a kind of knowledge in our brain.



Questions to think about - How many ways are there to spell the sound â€˜iâ€™ in English? - How many ways are there to pronounce the letter a in English? - French eau â€˜waterâ€™ is pronounced - Why pterodactylus does not sound out everything but sounds out only [tÉ›É¹É™dÃ¦ktÉªlÉ™s]?

title: 4Â  Phonology I
text:
4.5 3. Language X
Suppose that the following rule exists in Language X:

/t/ â†’ [d] / voiced __

(in words: The phoneme /t/ becomes [d] when it occurs after a voiced sound.)
Assume there are no instances of [d] in the language except those that arise from rule (i).
Answer the following questions based on the information given above.
A. What is the feature that is changing when /t/ becomes [d]?
[+voice] (or voicing)
B. What type of rule is rule (i)?

Assimilation
Dissimilation
Insertion
Deletion
Metathesis

C. Give the phonemic representation of the following words in Language X (provided in phonetic form).

/kontiv/ => [kondiv]
/lestun/ => [lestun]

D. Give the predicted phonetic form of the following word in Language X (provided in phonemic form).

/vÉ‘tfiÅ‹/ => [vÉ‘dfiÅ‹]
/nukti/ => [nukdi]

E. ____ If you looked at the way words are pronounced in Language X, you would find that the phones [t] and [d] occur in â€¦

free variation
overlapping distribution
complementary distribution

F. ____ The relationship between the phones [t] and [d] in Language X is that â€¦

there is no way to know from the information given here
they are allophones of the same phoneme
they are from separate phonemes
